name: Powdery Mildew
description: A fungal disease that appears as white or grayish powdery spots on leaves and stems. Thrives in moderate temperatures and high humidity with poor air circulation.
symptoms: White or gray powdery patches on leaves, stems, and flowers
Leaves may yellow, dry out, and drop prematurely
treatmentMethods: Remove and destroy infected plant parts
Fungicide sprays (e.g., neem oil, potassium bicarbonate, or sulfur-based)
Avoid overhead watering, water at the base of the plant

name: Root Rot
description: Caused by overwatering and poorly draining soil, leading to oxygen deprivation and fungal/bacterial growth on roots. Roots become mushy and brown/black.
symptoms: Wilting leaves, even when soil is moist
Yellowing or browning leaves, starting from the bottom of the plant
Mushy, dark, and foul-smelling roots (if plant is unpotted for inspection)
treatmentMethods: Allow soil to dry completely before re-evaluating watering needs
Ensure pots have adequate drainage holes and use a well-draining potting mix
For affected plants: remove, trim away rotted roots with sterile tool, repot in fresh sterile soil
Water less frequently; check soil moisture before watering

name: Fungal Leaf Spot
description: A common group of diseases caused by various fungi, resulting in spots on plant leaves. Spot appearance (color, size, shape) can vary widely based on the specific fungus and plant.
symptoms: Circular or irregular spots on leaves (often brown, black, tan, or yellow)
Spots may develop a distinct border, a target-like pattern, or a colored halo
Affected leaf tissue may die and fall out, creating a 'shot-hole' appearance
Severe infections can lead to significant leaf drop and reduced plant health
treatmentMethods: Remove and destroy affected leaves immediately to reduce spore spread
Improve air circulation and avoid prolonged leaf wetness by watering at the soil level
Apply appropriate fungicides (copper-based, neem oil, or specific to fungus type) if problem persists
Clean up fallen debris around plants regularly

name: Damping Off
description: A soil-borne fungal disease primarily affecting seedlings, causing them to rot at the soil line and collapse. Often occurs in overly wet, cool conditions with poor air circulation.
symptoms: Seedlings fail to emerge from the soil
Emerged seedlings suddenly wilt and collapse at the soil line
Stems appear constricted, water-soaked, or discolored near the soil
White, cobweb-like fungal growth may be visible on soil or affected seedlings
treatmentMethods: Use sterile seed-starting mix and clean containers
Avoid overwatering; keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged
Ensure good air circulation around seedlings (e.g., a small fan)
Sow seeds thinly to prevent overcrowding
Once started, there's no cure for affected seedlings; remove them to prevent spread
